chunks.text:
SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE.
     This Act may be cited as the ``Social Security Fairness Act of
2023''.

SEC. 2. REPEAL OF GOVERNMENT PENSION OFFSET PROVISION.
    (a) In General.--Section 202(k) of the Social Security Act (42
U.S.C. 402(k)) is amended by striking paragraph (5).
    (b) Conforming Amendments.--
        (1) Section 202(b)(2) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C.
    402(b)(2)) is amended by striking ``subsections (k)(5) and (q)''
    and inserting ``subsection (q)''.
        (2) Section 202(c)(2) of such Act (42 U.S.C. 402(c)(2)) is
    amended by striking ``subsections (k)(5) and (q)'' and inserting
    ``subsection (q)''.
        (3) Section 202(e)(2)(A) of such Act (42 U.S.C. 402(e)(2)(A))
    is amended by striking ``subsection (k)(5), subsection (q),'' and
    inserting ``subsection (q)''.
        (4) Section 202(f)(2)(A) of such Act (42 U.S.C. 402(f)(2)(A))
    is amended by striking ``subsection (k)(5), subsection (q)'' and
    inserting ``subsection (q)''.
chunks.section_title: REPEAL OF GOVERNMENT PENSION OFFSET PROVISION.

chunks.text:
SEC. 3. REPEAL OF WINDFALL ELIMINATION PROVISIONS.
    (a) In General.--Section 215 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C.
415) is amended--
        (1) in subsection (a), by striking paragraph (7);
        (2) in subsection (d), by striking paragraph (3); and
        (3) in subsection (f), by striking paragraph (9).
    (b) Conforming Amendments.--Subsections (e)(2) and (f)(2) of

section 202 of such Act (42 U.S.C. 402) are each amended by striking
``section 215(f)(5), 215(f)(6), or 215(f)(9)(B)'' in subparagraphs (C)
and (D)(i) and inserting ``paragraph (5) or (6) of section 215(f)''.
chunks.section_title: of such Act (42 U.S.C. 402) are each amended by striking

chunks.text:
SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE.
     The amendments made by this Act shall apply with respect to
monthly insurance benefits payable under title II of the Social
Security Act for months after December 2023. Notwithstanding section
215(f) of the Social Security Act, the Commissioner of Social Security
shall adjust primary insurance amounts to the extent necessary to take
into account the amendments made by section 3.

                               Speaker of the House of Representatives.

                            Vice President of the United States and
                                               President of the Senate.

analysis.plain_english_summary:
The Social Security Fairness Act of 2023 eliminates two provisions that currently reduce Social Security benefits for certain public sector workers and their families. The bill repeals the Government Pension Offset (GPO) and the Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP), which are rules that decrease Social Security payments for people who receive pensions from jobs where they did not pay Social Security taxes, such as some government employees, teachers, and public safety workers. By removing these offsets, the bill would allow affected individuals to receive their full Social Security benefits without reductions based on their public sector pensions.

The bill achieves this by amending specific sections of the Social Security Act. It removes the Government Pension Offset provision found in Section 202(k)(5), which currently reduces spousal and survivor benefits for people who receive government pensions. It also eliminates the Windfall Elimination Provision from Section 215, which currently uses a different formula to calculate retirement benefits for workers with non-Social Security covered employment. The bill includes several conforming amendments that update references throughout the Social Security Act to reflect these deletions, ensuring the law remains internally consistent after these provisions are removed.

The changes would take effect for monthly Social Security benefits payable after December 2023. The Social Security Commissioner is directed to recalculate primary insurance amounts (the base figure used to determine benefit payments) as necessary to implement these changes. This means that eligible individuals would begin receiving their full, unreduced Social Security benefits starting in January 2024. The bill does not specify how many people would be affected or provide details about the fiscal impact of eliminating these offset provisions.
key_provisions: Repeals the Government Pension Offset (GPO) provision in Section 202(k)(5) of the Social Security Act, which currently reduces Social Security spousal or survivor benefits for individuals who receive government pensions.

Repeals the Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP) by striking paragraphs in Section 215 of the Social Security Act that reduce Social Security benefits for individuals who receive pensions from employment not covered by Social Security.
Applies these changes to monthly Social Security insurance benefits payable for months after December 2023, establishing an effective date for implementation.
Requires the Commissioner of Social Security to adjust primary insurance amounts as necessary to implement the repeal of the Windfall Elimination Provision.
Makes conforming amendments throughout the Social Security Act to remove references to the repealed GPO and WEP provisions in multiple subsections governing benefit calculations.
analysis.practical_impact:
This bill directly affects public sector workers and their families who receive both government pensions (from jobs not covered by Social Security, such as certain state, local, or federal positions) and Social Security benefits. Currently, two provisions reduce Social Security benefits for these individuals: the Government Pension Offset (GPO), which reduces spousal or survivor benefits, and the Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP), which reduces retirement benefits. The bill eliminates both provisions, meaning affected individuals would receive their full Social Security benefits without reductions. For example, a retired teacher with a state pension who is also entitled to Social Security survivor benefits from a deceased spouse would no longer see those survivor benefits reduced or eliminated.

The changes apply to monthly benefits payable after December 2023, meaning eligible individuals would see increased payments beginning in early 2024. Those currently receiving reduced benefits would have their payments recalculated and increased. Those not yet receiving benefits but who will become eligible would receive full benefits without the previous reductions. The bill requires the Commissioner of Social Security to adjust benefit calculations as necessary to implement these changes. The practical effect is increased monthly income for an estimated 2-3 million current and future beneficiaries who worked in non-Social Security-covered government jobs, though the exact number of affected individuals is not specified in the bill text.

The bill does not affect individuals who only receive Social Security benefits from private sector employment, nor does it change benefit calculations for those who never worked in government positions without Social Security coverage. It is a mandatory change that automatically applies to all eligible beneficiaries without requiring them to take any action, though they may need to contact the Social Security Administration if their payments are not automatically adjusted.
